llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL error response returns a suggestion containing an existing field name (\"comment\") and indicates the schema type (Query). This leaks schema information which allows an attacker to enumerate available fields/types and craft further queries\u2014effectively providing introspection-like information even if standard introspection queries are disabled. This is an information disclosure risk that can facilitate targeted attacks. Recommendation: suppress detailed validation/suggestion messages in production, disable GraphQL introspection in public environments, or gate schema discovery behind authentication/authorization.", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". Did you mean \\\"comment\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". Did you mean \\\"comment\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error response returns a suggestion containing an existing field name (\"comment\") and indicates the schema type (Query). This leaks schema information which allows an attacker to enumerate available fields/types and craft further queries\u2014effectively providing introspection-like information even if standard introspection queries are disabled. This is an information disclosure risk that can facilitate targeted attacks. Recommendation: suppress detailed validation/suggestion messages in production, disable GraphQL introspection in public environments, or gate schema discovery behind authentication/authorization."}}]

llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "safe", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL server returns corrective suggestions in validation errors (\"Did you mean 'email'?\", \"Did you mean 'title'?\"). These suggestions reveal valid field names and parts of the schema to an unauthenticated requester, which facilitates schema discovery and targeted probing. This is an information disclosure issue (field_suggestions). While not directly leading to data exfiltration or remote code execution, it lowers the cost of reconnaissance for an attacker and can be combined with other techniques to mount further attacks. Remediation: disable verbose field suggestion messages in production or return generic validation errors, and log detailed diagnostics server-side only.", "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"emaill\\\" on type \\\"Comment\\\". Did you mean \\\"email\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"titel\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"email\\\"?\" and \"Cannot query field \\\"titel\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\" (also: \"Field \\\"postId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\".\")", "explanation": "The GraphQL server returns corrective suggestions in validation errors (\"Did you mean 'email'?\", \"Did you mean 'title'?\"). These suggestions reveal valid field names and parts of the schema to an unauthenticated requester, which facilitates schema discovery and targeted probing. This is an information disclosure issue (field_suggestions). While not directly leading to data exfiltration or remote code execution, it lowers the cost of reconnaissance for an attacker and can be combined with other techniques to mount further attacks. Remediation: disable verbose field suggestion messages in production or return generic validation errors, and log detailed diagnostics server-side only."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: Introspection (schema disclosure via error messages)", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL error response is leaking schema information by naming types and suggesting existing fields (e.g., 'comment'). Although this is not a direct __schema introspection query, returning field names and type information in error messages allows an attacker to enumerate available queries/mutations and infer schema structure. This is a form of introspection/information disclosure that aids reconnaissance and may be used to craft further attacks. Recommendation: suppress or genericize GraphQL validation errors in production (remove field suggestions), restrict or disable introspection for unauthenticated users, and implement error masking/logging on the server side.", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". Did you mean \\\"comment\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Introspection (schema disclosure via error messages)", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". Did you mean \\\"comment\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error response is leaking schema information by naming types and suggesting existing fields (e.g., 'comment'). Although this is not a direct __schema introspection query, returning field names and type information in error messages allows an attacker to enumerate available queries/mutations and infer schema structure. This is a form of introspection/information disclosure that aids reconnaissance and may be used to craft further attacks. Recommendation: suppress or genericize GraphQL validation errors in production (remove field suggestions), restrict or disable introspection for unauthenticated users, and implement error masking/logging on the server side."}}]

llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error responses reveal valid field names and input type details via 'Did you mean ...' suggestions and explicit field-not-defined messages. These suggestions leak schema information (e.g., 'email', 'name', 'body', 'CreateCommentInput' shape) that an attacker can use to enumerate the API, craft targeted queries, and map the schema. This is an information-disclosure issue (field_suggestions). Mitigation: disable or suppress field-suggestion hints and detailed validation messages in production, turn off debug mode, return generic validation errors, restrict introspection to authenticated/authorized clients, and apply rate limiting to reduce automated enumeration. Did you mean \\\"body\\\"?\" (also: \"Field \\\"postId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\".\")", "explanation": "The GraphQL error responses reveal valid field names and input type details via 'Did you mean ...' suggestions and explicit field-not-defined messages. These suggestions leak schema information (e.g., 'email', 'name', 'body', 'CreateCommentInput' shape) that an attacker can use to enumerate the API, craft targeted queries, and map the schema. This is an information-disclosure issue (field_suggestions). Mitigation: disable or suppress field-suggestion hints and detailed validation messages in production, turn off debug mode, return generic validation errors, restrict introspection to authenticated/authorized clients, and apply rate limiting to reduce automated enumeration. "}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL schema introspection (error message leakage)", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response exposes internal schema details in validation error messages: input type names (CreateCommentInput), required fields (name, email, body with type String!), fields that do not exist (postId, authorId, content), and type names (Comment). This is effectively schema introspection via error leakage and allows an attacker to enumerate types and fields, craft valid queries/mutations, and increase the effectiveness of further attacks. Recommend suppressing detailed schema errors in production (return generic error messages), disable or restrict introspection where appropriate, and implement error masking/logging for internal use only.", "evidence": "Error messages referencing types and fields: \"Field \\\"CreateCommentInput.name\\\" of required type \\\"String!\\\" was not provided.\", \"Field \\\"CreateCommentInput.email\\\"...\", \"Field \\\"CreateCommentInput.body\\\"...\", \"Field \\\"postId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\".\", \"Cannot query field \\\"content\\\" on type \\\"Comment\\\".\", \"Cannot query field \\\"author\\\" on type \\\"Comment\\\".\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "GraphQL schema introspection (error message leakage)", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "Error messages referencing types and fields: \"Field \\\"CreateCommentInput.name\\\" of required type \\\"String!\\\" was not provided.\", \"Field \\\"CreateCommentInput.email\\\"...\", \"Field \\\"CreateCommentInput.body\\\"...\", \"Field \\\"postId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\".\", \"Cannot query field \\\"content\\\" on type \\\"Comment\\\".\", \"Cannot query field \\\"author\\\" on type \\\"Comment\\\".\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response exposes internal schema details in validation error messages: input type names (CreateCommentInput), required fields (name, email, body with type String!), fields that do not exist (postId, authorId, content), and type names (Comment). This is effectively schema introspection via error leakage and allows an attacker to enumerate types and fields, craft valid queries/mutations, and increase the effectiveness of further attacks. Recommend suppressing detailed schema errors in production (return generic error messages), disable or restrict introspection where appropriate, and implement error masking/logging for internal use only."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error responses expose internal schema details (required input fields and undefined/misspelled field names). Although this is not direct code injection, leaking schema constraints and valid field names increases attack surface. This is a field-suggestions/information-disclosure issue: attackers can use these validation errors to enumerate types and required fields, craft more targeted queries or inputs, and aid further probing. Although this is not direct code injection, leaking schema constraints and valid field names increases attack surface. Mitigation: return generic validation errors in production (do not leak field/type names), disable introspection or tighten it in production, and implement rate-limiting and logging for probing attempts."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL Schema Disclosure (Introspection)", "detection": "safe", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL API returned a validation error that explicitly names a schema type (CreateCommentInput) and a field (postId). This is information disclosure of the GraphQL schema (schema/type/field names), which facilitates reconnaissance and can be used to craft targeted queries or discover other operations even if __introspection__ queries are disabled. While this does not itself execute queries or expose sensitive data, leaking type and field names is a form of introspection/ schema exposure and should be treated as an information disclosure risk. Recommended mitigations: suppress detailed schema validation errors in production, return generic error messages, and harden GraphQL server configuration to avoid leaking schema details.", "evidence": "\"message\": \"Field \\\"postId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\".\"", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "GraphQL Schema Disclosure (Introspection)", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "\"message\": \"Field \\\"postId\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\".\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL API returned a validation error that explicitly names a schema type (CreateCommentInput) and a field (postId). This is information disclosure of the GraphQL schema (schema/type/field names), which facilitates reconnaissance and can be used to craft targeted queries or discover other operations even if __introspection__ queries are disabled. While this does not itself execute queries or expose sensitive data, leaking type and field names is a form of introspection/ schema exposure and should be treated as an information disclosure risk. Recommended mitigations: suppress detailed schema validation errors in production, return generic error messages, and harden GraphQL server configuration to avoid leaking schema details."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL Introspection / Schema Disclosure", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns detailed validation errors that disclose internal schema information: type names (CreateCommentInput, Comment), required field names and types (name: String!, email: String!, body: String!), and which fields exist or do not exist. Such information disclosure aids attackers in crafting targeted queries, brute-forcing possible operations, and discovering exploitable inputs. This effectively provides the attacker with the API schema/field layout (schema introspection) even if the formal introspection endpoint is disabled. Such information disclosure aids attackers in crafting targeted queries, brute-forcing possible operations, and discovering exploitable inputs. Recommended mitigations: suppress or genericize validation error messages returned to clients in production, disable GraphQL introspection in production if not required, implement schema-level access controls, and log detailed errors server-side only."}}]

llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: xss_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response for createComment contains the submitted comment body unencoded and includes a raw <script> tag: \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\". This indicates the API is reflecting/storing HTML/JavaScript content without sanitization or encoding. If a web client renders this field into a page without proper output escaping or a strict Content Security Policy, an attacker could achieve stored XSS that executes in other users' browsers (including admins), leading to session theft, CSRF, or other actions. Recommended mitigations: 1) Treat this field as untrusted data and apply proper output encoding/escaping when rendering into HTML (e.g., HTML-escape <, >, &). 2) Implement server-side input validation/sanitization based on allowed content (or disallow HTML/script in comment bodies). 3) Use a strict Content Security Policy to reduce impact of injected scripts. 4) Audit other fields/endpoints for similar behavior.", "evidence": "\"body\": \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\" in createComment response", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "xss_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "\"body\": \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\" in createComment response", "explanation": "The GraphQL response for createComment contains the submitted comment body unencoded and includes a raw <script> tag: \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\". This indicates the API is reflecting/storing HTML/JavaScript content without sanitization or encoding. If a web client renders this field into a page without proper output escaping or a strict Content Security Policy, an attacker could achieve stored XSS that executes in other users' browsers (including admins), leading to session theft, CSRF, or other actions. Recommended mitigations: 1) Treat this field as untrusted data and apply proper output encoding/escaping when rendering into HTML (e.g., HTML-escape <, >, &). 2) Implement server-side input validation/sanitization based on allowed content (or disallow HTML/script in comment bodies). 3) Use a strict Content Security Policy to reduce impact of injected scripts. 4) Audit other fields/endpoints for similar behavior."}}]
